defs.name: verify_membership
defs.value:
pub fn verify_membership<impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>: ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>>(&Self,
                                                                                      &LeafH::ParametersVar,
                                                                                      &TwoToOneH::ParametersVar,
                                                                                      &TwoToOneH::OutputVar,
                                                                                      &impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>)
-> Result<Boolean<ConstraintF>, SynthesisError>
defs.docs:
Check that hashing a Merkle tree path according to `self`, and
 with `leaf` as the leaf, leads to a Merkle tree root equalling `root`.

attributes.value: / Check that hashing a Merkle tree path according to `self`, and
/ with `leaf` as the leaf, leads to a Merkle tree root equalling `root`.

defs.name: update_leaf
defs.value:
pub fn update_leaf<impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>: ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>,
                   impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>: ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>>(&Self,
                                                                                &LeafH::ParametersVar,
                                                                                &TwoToOneH::ParametersVar,
                                                                                &TwoToOneH::OutputVar,
                                                                                &impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>,
                                                                                &impl ToBytesGadget<ConstraintF>)
-> Result<TwoToOneH::OutputVar, SynthesisError>
defs.docs:
Check that `old_leaf` is the leaf of the Merkle tree on the path defined by
 `self`, and then compute the new root when replacing `old_leaf` by `new_leaf`.

attributes.value: / Check that `old_leaf` is the leaf of the Merkle tree on the path defined by
/ `self`, and then compute the new root when replacing `old_leaf` by `new_leaf`.

defs.docs:
Check that `old_leaf` is the leaf of the Merkle tree on the path defined by
 `self`, and then compute the expected new root when replacing `old_leaf` by `new_leaf`.
 Return a boolean indicating whether expected new root equals `new_root`.

/ `self`, and then compute the expected new root when replacing `old_leaf` by `new_leaf`.
/ Return a boolean indicating whether expected new root equals `new_root`.

defs.name: Path
defs.docs:
Stores the hashes of a particular path (in order) from root to leaf.
 For example:
 ```tree_diagram
         [A]
        /   \
      [B]    C
     / \   /  \
    D [E] F    H
   .. / \ ....
    [I] J
 ```
  Suppose we want to prove I, then `leaf_sibling_hash` is J, `auth_path` is `[C,D]`

attributes.value: / Stores the hashes of a particular path (in order) from root to leaf.
/  Suppose we want to prove I, then `leaf_sibling_hash` is J, `auth_path` is `[C,D]`

defs.name: auth_path
defs.docs: The sibling of path node ordered from higher layer to lower layer (does not include root node).

attributes.value: / The sibling of path node ordered from higher layer to lower layer (does not include root node).

defs.name: leaf_index
defs.docs: stores the leaf index of the node

attributes.value: / stores the leaf index of the node

defs.value:
pub fn verify(&Self, &LeafParam

, &TwoToOneParam

, &TwoToOneDigest

, &L) -> Result
defs.docs:
Verify that a leaf is at `self.index` of the merkle tree.
 * `leaf_size`: leaf size in number of bytes

attributes.value: / Verify that a leaf is at `self.index` of the merkle tree.
/ * `leaf_size`: leaf size in number of bytes
/ `verify` infers the tree height by setting `tree_height = self.auth_path.len() + 2`

defs.name: MerkleTree
defs.docs:
Defines a merkle tree data structure.
 This merkle tree has runtime fixed height, and assumes number of leaves is 2^height.

attributes.value: / Defines a merkle tree data structure.
/ This merkle tree has runtime fixed height, and assumes number of leaves is 2^height.
/ TODO: add RFC-6962 compatible merkle tree in the future.
/ For this release, padding will not be supported because of security concerns: if the leaf hash and two to one hash uses same underlying
/ CRH, a malicious prover can prove a leaf while the actual node is an inner node. In the future, we can prefix leaf hashes in different layers to

defs.name: update
defs.value: pub fn update<L: ToBytes>(&mut Self, usize, &L) -> Result<(), crate::Error>
defs.docs:
Update the leaf at `index` to updated leaf.
 ```tree_diagram
         [A]
        /   \
      [B]    C
     / \   /  \
    D [E] F    H
   .. / \ ....
    [I] J
 ```
 update(3, {new leaf}) would swap the leaf value at `[I]` and cause a recomputation of `[A]`, `[B]`, and `[E]`.

attributes.value: / Update the leaf at `index` to updated leaf.
/ update(3, {new leaf}) would swap the leaf value at `[I]` and cause a recomputation of `[A]`, `[B]`, and `[E]`.

) -> Result

attributes.value: / Update the leaf and check if the updated root is equal to `asserted_new_root`.
/ Tree will not be modified if the check fails.

defs.name: VerifyingKeyVar
InputVar
defs.value: type InputVar: AllocVar<Vec<F>, ConstraintF> + FromFieldElementsGadget<F, ConstraintF> + Clone;

defs.name: VerifierSize
defs.docs:
Information about the R1CS constraints required to check proofs relative
 a given verification key. In the context of a LPCP-based pairing-based SNARK
 like that of [[Groth16]](https://eprint.iacr.org/2016/260),
 this is independent of the R1CS matrices,
 whereas for more "complex" SNARKs like [[Marlin]](https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/1047),
 this can encode information about the highest degree of polynomials
 required to verify proofs.

attributes.value: / Information about the R1CS constraints required to check proofs relative
/ a given verification key. In the context of a LPCP-based pairing-based SNARK
/ this is independent of the R1CS matrices,
/ this can encode information about the highest degree of polynomials

defs.name: verifier_size
defs.docs:
Returns information about the R1CS constraints required to check proofs relative
 to the verification key `circuit_vk`.

attributes.value: / Returns information about the R1CS constraints required to check proofs relative

defs.name: new_proof_unchecked
defs.value:
pub fn new_proof_unchecked<T: Borrow<S::Proof>,
                           impl Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>: Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>,
                           impl FnOnce() -> Result<T, SynthesisError>: FnOnce()
                           ->
                           Result<T,
                                  SynthesisError>>(impl Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>,
                                                   impl FnOnce() -> Result<T, SynthesisError>,
                                                   AllocationMode)
-> Result<Self::ProofVar, SynthesisError>
defs.docs:
Optionally allocates `S::Proof` in `cs` without performing
 additional checks, such as subgroup membership checks. Use this *only*
 if you know it is safe to do so. Such "safe" scenarios can include
 the case where `proof` is a public input (`mode == AllocationMode::Input`),
 and the corresponding checks are performed by the SNARK verifier outside
 the circuit.  Another example is the when `mode == AllocationMode::Constant`.

defs.name: new_verification_key_unchecked
defs.value:
pub fn new_verification_key_unchecked<T: Borrow<S::VerifyingKey>,
                                      impl Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>: Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>,
                                      impl FnOnce() -> Result<T, SynthesisError>: FnOnce()
                                      ->
                                      Result<T,
                                             SynthesisError>>(impl Into<Namespace<ConstraintF>>,
                                                              impl FnOnce() -> Result<T, SynthesisError>,
                                                              AllocationMode)
-> Result<Self::VerifyingKeyVar, SynthesisError>
defs.docs:
Optionally allocates `S::VerifyingKey` in `cs` without performing
 additional checks, such as subgroup membership checks. Use this *only*
 if you know it is safe to do so. Such "safe" scenarios can include
 the case where `vk` is a public input (`mode == AllocationMode::Input`),
 and the corresponding checks are performed by the SNARK verifier outside
 the circuit. Another example is the when `mode == AllocationMode::Constant`.
